security_audit.summary: The algorithmic-art skill is a well-structured educational tool for creating generative art with p5.js. It emphasizes reproducible, seeded randomness and provides a clear template-based workflow. No security vulnerabilities, injection risks, or malicious patterns detected. The skill encourages creative, original work and explicitly warns against copyright violations.

low_findings.title: CDN Dependency Risk
low_findings.description: The skill relies on p5.js served from cdnjs.cloudflare.com. While this is a standard practice, offline users or environments with restricted network access won't be able to use the skill. The documentation could mention this dependency.
low_findings.mitigation: Already acceptable for standard use cases. Consider documenting fallback options for restricted environments.

content.value_statement: Transform your creative vision into gallery-quality generative art using p5.js. Create reproducible, seeded algorithmic compositions with precise parameter control. Explore infinite variations of your design through interactive seed navigation—a skill for generative artists, creative technologists, and algorithmic designers.
actual_capabilities: Generate reproducible algorithmic art using seeded randomness
Create interactive p5.js sketches with parameter controls
Design parametric variations (particle counts, noise scales, speeds, colors)
Build self-contained HTML artifacts with embedded algorithms
Navigate seed space to explore infinite variations
Use flow fields, particle systems, recursive structures, and noise-based generation
Customize UI with Anthropic branding and design tokens
limitations: Requires understanding of algorithmic thinking and mathematical concepts
Cannot generate static images directly—focuses on procedural generation
Limited to p5.js; other graphics frameworks require custom implementation
Large particle counts (>50k) may impact browser performance
No built-in support for 3D or WebGL rendering (p5.js has basic 3D, but skill emphasizes 2D)
Offline use requires locally hosting p5.js library

use_cases.title: Interactive Art Installation
use_cases.description: Create a generative art piece that visitors can customize via parameter controls. Each seed produces a unique composition. Perfect for galleries, museums, or digital exhibitions.
use_cases.target_user: Digital artists, gallery curators, interactive designers

use_cases.title: Procedural Game Assets
use_cases.description: Generate textures, landscapes, or procedural patterns for games. Use seeded randomness to create repeatable environments or unique-per-playthrough content.

use_cases.title: Design System Exploration
use_cases.description: Parameterize visual patterns (color palettes, spacing, flow) and explore thousands of variations to find optimal design directions.
use_cases.target_user: Graphic designers, UI/UX designers, design systems engineers

use_cases.title: Educational Visualization
use_cases.description: Create interactive visualizations of mathematical concepts, natural systems, or algorithms. Parameters teach how small changes produce emergent complexity.

use_cases.title: Generative NFT or Print Series
use_cases.description: Create a unique artwork for each seed. Generate high-resolution exports for fine art prints or blockchain-based collections.
use_cases.target_user: Digital artists, NFT creators, print artists

use_cases.title: Brand Visualization
use_cases.description: Build a unique generative brand asset that reflects company values through algorithmic design—organic, parametric, and infinitely explorable.
use_cases.target_user: Creative directors, brand designers, marketing teams

prompt_templates.title: Flow Field Art
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a generative art piece inspired by [aesthetic concept], using particles that flow through a vector field. The piece should feel [descriptive quality] with these parameters: particle count, flow speed, noise scale, and trail length. Make it interactive so users can explore variations.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants flowing, organic particle art with mathematical underpinnings

prompt_templates.title: Recursive Structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an algorithmic art piece that grows through recursive subdivision and branching. The structure should embody [philosophical concept] with subtle randomization to break perfect symmetry. Include parameters for recursion depth, branch angles, and scaling ratios.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants tree-like, fractal, or self-similar organic patterns

prompt_templates.title: Interference & Harmonics
prompt_templates.prompt: Create generative art using harmonic wave interference. Particles should exhibit [wave behavior], with their interactions creating emergent mandalas or nodal patterns. Parameters should control frequencies, phases, and particle density.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants mathematical beauty based on wave physics or interference patterns

prompt_templates.title: Cellular Evolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a generative artwork using cellular automata or agent-based simulation. The system should evolve according to [rules/behaviors], creating emergent complexity from simple local interactions. Include parameters for rule variations, speed, and color mapping.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants evolving systems, life-like patterns, or emergent behavior

prompt_templates.title: Stochastic Crystallization
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an art piece using randomized circle packing or Voronoi tessellation. Particles relax to equilibrium, creating organic crystalline patterns. Parameters should control relaxation speed, density, and color mapping.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants organic tiling, cell patterns, or natural crystalline growth

output_examples.input: Create a flow field art piece inspired by underwater currents with organic movement
output_examples.output: An interactive HTML artifact displaying particles flowing through layered Perlin noise vector fields. The visualization shows 5000 particles with trailing paths, creating the impression of water flowing around invisible obstacles. Parameters allow adjustment of particle count, flow speed, noise octaves, and trail length. The seed navigation lets users explore variations from calm, organized flows to chaotic turbulent patterns. Color palette uses ocean blues and teals. Fully reproducible—the same seed always produces identical output.

output_examples.input: Generate recursive tree art with subtle randomization and autumn colors
output_examples.output: An interactive sketch showing branching structures that recursively subdivide. Each branch slightly randomized but constrained by golden ratios and natural growth rules. Line weights diminish with recursion depth, creating depth perception. Parameters control recursion depth, branch angle variation, and color mapping from palette of warm oranges, browns, and deep reds. The algorithm runs once per seed and creates a unique tree structure. Users navigate seeds to find pleasing compositions.

output_examples.input: Create interactive particle art exploring wave interference patterns
output_examples.output: A visual composition where particles are positioned on a grid with evolving phase values. As particles move in proximity, their phases interfere—constructive interference creates bright nodes, destructive creates voids. The result is mandala-like patterns with radial symmetry and unexpected complexity. Parameters tune harmonic frequencies, interference strength, and particle density. Each seed creates a unique harmonic composition. The piece is fully animated, showing the wave patterns emerging in real-time.

best_practices: Start with the SKILL.md philosophy section—read it before implementing to understand the creative direction
Use seeded randomness consistently; same seed should ALWAYS produce identical output
Keep parameters minimal and meaningful—every control should be tunable, not decorative
Test parameter extremes (min/max values) to ensure graceful degradation and no crashes
Emphasize the algorithm itself, not single static frames; let viewers explore through seed navigation
Use the template HTML as a true starting point—preserve Anthropic branding and structure, customize only the algorithm
Tune parameters as if the algorithm took countless iterations to perfect; avoid obvious randomness artifacts
Consider computational complexity; aim for <60ms per frame on modern hardware for smooth real-time animation
Design color palettes thoughtfully; avoid pure RGB noise—use harmonious palettes that guide visual hierarchy
Document the algorithmic philosophy before coding; let the philosophy guide implementation choices
anti_patterns: Don't copy existing artists' work without significant transformation or inspiration attribution
Don't use pure noise without constraints; add structure, rules, or field dynamics to guide emergence
Don't create parameters that look like a pattern menu ('Mode 1: Spiral', 'Mode 2: Grid')—parameters should be continuous/mathematical
Don't ignore seed reproducibility; use randomSeed() and noiseSeed() consistently
Don't create visual noise without hierarchy; ensure there's composition, focal points, and visual rhythm
Don't exceed performance budgets; optimize particle counts and calculation frequency for smooth 60fps
Don't design for hypothetical future features; implement what the vision demands, then stop
Don't reinvent the template; use the provided templates as-is for consistent UX and branding
Don't publish artwork that shows signs of rushed optimization; meticulously tune until it feels intentional

faq.question: Can I use this to create NFT art?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill produces reproducible artwork with seeded randomness, perfect for generative NFT series. Each seed produces a unique output that can be exported as PNG. Document the seed values for provenance and uniqueness tracking.

faq.question: What's the difference between this and AI image generation?
faq.answer: This creates procedural art—beauty emerges from algorithmic execution, not AI models. Every visual element is deterministic and reproducible. The artist controls the algorithm; randomness is controlled via seeds. This gives you precise creative control over emergence patterns.

faq.question: Can I animate the output?
faq.answer: Yes. Set `draw()` to run continuously rather than calling `noLoop()`. The animation will be smooth and reproducible for the same seed. You can adjust animation speed via parameters.

faq.question: How do I increase visual quality/resolution?
faq.answer: Increase canvas size in `createCanvas()` (e.g., 2000x2000 for high-res). Be mindful of performance—larger canvases with many particles may reduce frame rate. For high-resolution exports, generate at larger size, then export PNG.

faq.question: Can I use this offline?
faq.answer: The artifact requires p5.js from CDN. For offline use, download p5.js and modify the script source to point to a local copy. The rest is self-contained.

faq.question: What if I want to use a different graphics library?
faq.answer: The skill is optimized for p5.js. The algorithmic philosophy can be adapted to Three.js, Processing, Openframeworks, or other libraries, but you'd need to modify the template and implementation yourself.

faq.question: How do I share my generative art?
faq.answer: The HTML artifact is self-contained. Save it as a `.html` file and share it directly. Anyone can open it in any modern browser without installation. You can also screenshot/export PNG from within the artifact.

faq.question: Can I combine multiple algorithms?
faq.answer: Yes. Extend the Particle class or create additional systems. Be mindful of performance—combining complex systems increases computational load. Test with target hardware.

faq.question: Is this suitable for beginners?
faq.answer: The skill assumes basic familiarity with p5.js and algorithmic thinking. Beginners should first learn p5.js fundamentals, then apply those concepts through this skill. The philosophy-first approach helps guide algorithmic decisions.

faq.question: How do I ensure my artwork looks intentional, not random?
faq.answer: This is the core philosophy: constrain randomness with rules, fields, forces, or behaviors. Use noise rather than pure random. Add parameters that control emergence. Tune every setting as if it took countless iterations. The algorithm should feel meticulously crafted.

dependencies: Modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
permissions_needed: File system access (if saving/exporting PNG locally)
technical_requirements.notes: The skill provides templates and guidance. Setup involves understanding the philosophy, then implementing the p5.js algorithm. Complexity varies by algorithmic vision—simple flow fields take ~15 min, complex multi-system pieces take hours of iteration. The time investment pays off in learning procedural aesthetics and computational design.
